rev.diff:
Line 148: Line 148:
* '''November 2''' (11 PM){{ndash}}'''November 3''' (1 AM) â Later in the evening, a group of protesters took over a vacant building that once served as the headquarters of the Traveler's Aid Society, a non-profit organization that provided services to the local homeless population. Police soon arrived to break up the protesters gathered outside of the building. Some protesters fled while others set a barricade on fire.<ref>{{cite news|last=Loftis|first=Emily|title=Occupy Oakland shuts down port|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/11/03/occupy_oakland_shuts_down_port/|accessdate=November 4, 2011|newspaper=Salon|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref> Police used teargas and flash bangs to try to clear protesters.<ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland general strike â Thursday 3 November|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/03/occupy-oakland-general-strike-live#block-13|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Clashes continued past midnight. 103 people were arrested. Scott Campbell was shot by police using a [[Non-lethal_weapon#Ammunition|less-lethal round]] while he was filming a stationary line of police in riot gear.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57321440/experts-occupy-vid-shows-excessive-force/ Experts: "Occupy" video shows excessive force]</ref> Kayvan Sabeghi was seriously injured while being arrested by police that evening.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Occupy Oakland: second Iraq war veteran injured after police clashes|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/04/occupy-oakland-second-veteran-injured|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 2''' (11 PM){{ndash}}'''November 3''' (1 AM) â Later in the evening, a group of protesters took over a vacant building that once served as the headquarters of the Traveler's Aid Society, a non-profit organization that provided services to the local homeless population. Police soon arrived to break up the protesters gathered outside of the building. Some protesters fled while others set a barricade on fire.<ref>{{cite news|last=Loftis|first=Emily|title=Occupy Oakland shuts down port|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/11/03/occupy_oakland_shuts_down_port/|accessdate=November 4, 2011|newspaper=Salon|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref> Police used teargas and flash bangs to try to clear protesters.<ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland general strike â Thursday 3 November|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/03/occupy-oakland-general-strike-live#block-13|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Clashes continued past midnight. 103 people were arrested. Scott Campbell was shot by police using a [[Non-lethal_weapon#Ammunition|less-lethal round]] while he was filming a stationary line of police in riot gear.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57321440/experts-occupy-vid-shows-excessive-force/ Experts: "Occupy" video shows excessive force]</ref> Kayvan Sabeghi was seriously injured while being arrested by police that evening.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Occupy Oakland: second Iraq war veteran injured after police clashes|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/04/occupy-oakland-second-veteran-injured|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref>
â
* '''November 3''' â After 18 hours of being denied medical treatment while in police custody, Kayvan Sabeghi was transferred to [[Highland Hospital (Oakland, California)|Highland Hospital]] and put into the intensive care unit.<ref name=kayvan_reuters>{{cite news|last=Randewich|first=Noel|title=Army veteran injured in Oakland clashes with police|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/05/us-protests-oakland-veteran-idUSTRE7A37A820111105|accessdate=6 November 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=4 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Kayvan Sabeghi Injured: Second Iraq war vet hurt during Oakland clash with police|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/05/kayvan-sabeghi-injured_n_1077806.html|accessdate=5 November 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=5 November 2011}}</ref> Journalist Susie Cagle was arrested in the early hours of November 3, jailed, and ultimately charged with a misdemeanor. Cagle subsequently reported having observed mistreatment of protesters during their imprisonment.<ref>[http://www.alternet.org/story/152990/police_state_in_oakland_one_reporter%27s_arrest_contradicts_official_story/?page=entire]</ref>
+
* '''November 3''' â After 18 hours of being denied medical treatment while in police custody, Kayvan Sabeghi was transferred to [[Highland Hospital (Oakland, California)|Highland Hospital]] and put into the intensive care unit.<ref name=kayvan_reuters>{{cite news|last=Randewich|first=Noel|title=Army veteran injured in Oakland clashes with police|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/05/us-protests-oakland-veteran-idUSTRE7A37A820111105|accessdate=6 November 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=4 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Kayvan Sabeghi Injured: Second Iraq war vet hurt during Oakland clash with police|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/05/kayvan-sabeghi-injured_n_1077806.html|accessdate=5 November 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=5 November 2011}}</ref> Journalist Susie Cagle was arrested in the early hours of November 3, jailed, and ultimately charged with a misdemeanor. Cagle subsequently reported having observed mistreatment of protesters during their imprisonment.<ref>[http://www.alternet.org/story/152990/police_state_in_oakland_one_reporter%27s_arrest_contradicts_official_story/?page=entire]</ref> The [[Oakland Metropolitan Chamber of Commerce]] issued a [http://www.scribd.com/doc/71505592/Chamber-of-Commerce-Response-to-Proposed-Resolution-Letter letter] calling for the eviction of the protestors.
â
* '''November 4''' â The Oakland City Council held a five hour meeting to consider a resolution by council member [[Nancy Nadel]] in support of the Occupy Oakland encampment. The council heard over 100 people speak about the positives and negatives of Occupy Oakland. The vote on the resolution was postponed until the November 15 city council meeting.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tense Meeting Reveals Deep Divisions over Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/tense-meeting-reveals-deep-divisions/|accessdate=November 5, 2011|publisher=The Bay Citizen|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref>
+
* '''November 4''' â The Oakland City Council held a five hour meeting to consider a resolution by council member [[Nancy Nadel]] in support of the Occupy Oakland encampment. The council heard over 100 people speak about the positives and negatives of Occupy Oakland. Oakland Metropolitan Chamber of Commerce President [[Joe Haraburda]] said,"We have made our position clear.â¦ We want Occupy Oakland closed."<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2011/nov/04/local/la-me-occupy-oakland-20111104 Occupy Oakland debated at public forum] The vote on the resolution was postponed until the November 15 city council meeting.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tense Meeting Reveals Deep Divisions over Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/tense-meeting-reveals-deep-divisions/|accessdate=November 5, 2011|publisher=The Bay Citizen|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref>
â
* '''November 5''' â A downtown Oakland Wells Fargo branch closed for business because of the roughly 100 immigrant rights protesters who marched from Occupy Oakland's encampment to protest the bank's connection to companies that run [[Immigration detention in the United States|immigrant detention centers]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Wohlsen|first=Marcus|title=Protesters close down Oakland Wells Fargo branch|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/11/05/state/n134250D33.DTL|accessdate=November 5, 2011|newspaper=AP - San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 5, 2011}}</ref>
+
* '''November 5''' â A downtown Oakland Wells Fargo branch closed for business because of the roughly 100 immigrant rights protesters who marched from Occupy Oakland's encampment to protest the bank's connection to companies that run [[Immigration detention in the United States|immigrant detention centers]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Wohlsen|first=Marcus|title=Protesters close down Oakland Wells Fargo branch|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/11/05/state/n134250D33.DTL|accessdate=November 5, 2011|newspaper=AP - San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 5, 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 7''' â Occupy Oakland deposited $20,000 donated by Occupy Wall Street for urgent medical and legal expenses into Wells Fargo. The Occupy Oakland general assembly approved the decision to hold it temporarily in a Wells Fargo account so that it could begin being used immediately while the group waits on the state to finalize its status as an unincorporated association able to hold funds.<ref>[http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/2011/11/occupy-oakland-makes-20k-deposit-wells-fargo Occupy Oakland makes $20K deposit at Wells Fargo], San Francisco Examiner, November 8, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.occupyoakland.org/generalassembly/committees/ Occupy Oakland General Assembly statement on $20,000 donation]</ref><ref>[http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/09/occupy-oakland-protesters-deposit-funds-at-wells-fargo-after-bank-attacks/ Occupy Oakland Protesters Deposit Funds At Wells Fargo After Bank Attacks], CBS News, November 9, 2011</ref><ref>[http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8425918 'Occupy Oakland' opens bank account at Wells Fargo], ABC News, November 9, 2011</ref>
* '''November 7''' â Occupy Oakland deposited $20,000 donated by Occupy Wall Street for urgent medical and legal expenses into Wells Fargo. The Occupy Oakland general assembly approved the decision to hold it temporarily in a Wells Fargo account so that it could begin being used immediately while the group waits on the state to finalize its status as an unincorporated association able to hold funds.<ref>[http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/2011/11/occupy-oakland-makes-20k-deposit-wells-fargo Occupy Oakland makes $20K deposit at Wells Fargo], San Francisco Examiner, November 8, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.occupyoakland.org/generalassembly/committees/ Occupy Oakland General Assembly statement on $20,000 donation]</ref><ref>[http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/09/occupy-oakland-protesters-deposit-funds-at-wells-fargo-after-bank-attacks/ Occupy Oakland Protesters Deposit Funds At Wells Fargo After Bank Attacks], CBS News, November 9, 2011</ref><ref>[http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8425918 'Occupy Oakland' opens bank account at Wells Fargo], ABC News, November 9, 2011</ref>
Line 160: Line 160:
* '''November 10''' â A man was fatally shot near the Frank Ogawa Plaza encampment. <ref>{{cite news|title=Shots fired near 'Occupy Oakland,' one dead|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8427634|accessdate=November 10, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 10''' â A man was fatally shot near the Frank Ogawa Plaza encampment. <ref>{{cite news|title=Shots fired near 'Occupy Oakland,' one dead|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8427634|accessdate=November 10, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>
â
* '''November 11''' â The Oakland Police Officers Association release an open letter to Occupy Oakland stating that "it is time to go home." <ref>{{cite news|title=Oakland police union calls for end to "Occupy" camp|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/11/us-protests-oakland-idUSTRE7AA53020111111|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=November 11, 2011}}</ref> Oakland Police issue eviction notices to the demonstrators at the tent encampment. Veterans march and rally in downtown Oakland against police brutality.<ref>{{cite news|last=Woodall|first=Angela|title=Oakland police issue evictions notices at Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/occupy-oakland/ci_19319305?source=rss|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=Oakland Tribune|date=November 12, 2011}}</ref>
+
* '''November 11''' â The Oakland Police Officers Association release an open letter to Occupy Oakland stating that "it is time to go home." <ref>{{cite news|title=Oakland police union calls for end to "Occupy" camp|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/11/us-protests-oakland-idUSTRE7AA53020111111|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=November 11, 2011}}</ref> Oakland Police issue eviction notices to the demonstrators at the tent encampment. Veterans march and rally in downtown Oakland against police brutality.<ref>{{cite news|last=Woodall|first=Angela|title=Oakland police issue evictions notices at Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/occupy-oakland/ci_19319305?source=rss|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=Oakland Tribune|date=November 12, 2011}}</ref>
â   â
